text: Solve this problem step by step.
End with 'DONE.' when you have a solution.
Question: A man lives on the 10th floor of an apartment building.
Every morning he takes the elevator down to the ground floor to go to work.
In the evening, when he returns from work, he takes the elevator to the 7th floor and then walks up the stairs for the remaining three floors to his apartment.
However, on rainy days or when there are other people in the elevator, he goes directly to the 10th floor.

Why does he do this? 

 Solution: 
<think>
Alright, so I have this puzzle here about a man living on the 10th floor.
Let me try to figure out why he does what he does.
Okay, every morning, he takes the elevator down to the ground floor to go to work.
That makes sense because taking the elevator down is faster than walking up, especially if he's on the 10th floor.
In the evening, when he returns from work, he takes the elevator to the 7th floor and then walks up the stairs for three more floors to his apartment on the 10th floor.
Hmm, why doesn't he just take the elevator all the way up? Maybe there's something about the elevator's behavior that I'm missing.
Now, the tricky part is on rainy days or when there are other people in the elevator.
On those days, he goes directly to the 10th floor without stopping at the 7th.
So, what's different on rainy days or when there are people in the elevator? Maybe the elevator's operation changes under those conditions.
Wait, could it be that the elevator only goes up to the 7th floor on certain days? Like, maybe on rainy days or when it's busy, the elevator doesn't go beyond the 7th floor.
That would explain why he takes the elevator to the 7th and then walks up.
But on normal days, maybe the elevator goes all the way up to the 10th floor, so he doesn't need to walk.
But why would the elevator behave differently on rainy days or when there are people? Perhaps the elevator has a limit, like it can only go up to the 7th floor during those times.
So, on rainy days or when it's crowded, the elevator stops at the 7th floor and he has to walk the rest.
On normal days, the elevator goes all the way up, so he takes it directly to the 10th floor without walking.
Alternatively, maybe the elevator's speed or availability changes.
But the key seems to be the elevator's behavior based on certain conditions.
So, the man adjusts his routine accordingly to save time or avoid waiting.
Wait, another angle: maybe the elevator has a rule where it doesn't go beyond the 7th floor unless it's empty or certain conditions are met.
So, when it's raining or busy, the elevator only goes to the 7th floor, forcing him to walk up.
But on normal days, it goes all the way up, so he can take it directly.
I think that's the reason.
The elevator's operation is limited to the 7th floor under certain conditions, so he has to walk the remaining three floors.
On normal days, the elevator goes all the way, so he takes it up without walking.
So, to sum up, the man takes the elevator to the 7th floor in the evening because the elevator might not go higher on rainy days or when it's busy, so he has to walk up.
But in the morning, he takes the elevator all the way down, and in the evening, he takes it up only when it's not restricted.
I think that's the logic here.
The elevator's limitations based on weather or crowd level force him to adjust his path in the evening.

</think>

He does this because the elevator likely has a rule that stops at the 7th floor on rainy days or when it's busy, so he must walk up the stairs the remaining three floors.
In the morning, the elevator goes all the way down, and in the evening, it goes up to the 10th floor on normal days.
